title: The vital role of Quality Assurance in pensions calculations

content.text: A pensions administration professional’s perspective

In pensions administration, precision is paramount; errors can have a significant impact on someone’s post-retirement life. In the battle to mitigate and reduce errors, the role of quality assurance (QA) cannot be overstated.
As a senior pensions administrator who has worked for several of the leading administration providers, I have experienced firsthand the positive impact that QA has.

Mistakes can happen in anything that we do; they are an inevitable part of life. In the pensions world, they can arise through errors in numbers or in the way that we present and communicate information. They can be genuine errors or misinterpretations of data and information held on our administration systems. Some, due to poor or incomplete data, may be outside of the administrators’ control while others arise from individual or systemic issues within pension systems and processes.

Scheme administrators strive to get things right first time and work hard with their members and stakeholders to put things right when they go wrong. In the vast majority of cases, administrators provide good, clear and accurate information to their members. Very little is ever said about the considerable number of transactions and interactions that members have with their pension providers every day where things go right.

However, when an error arises, for whatever reason, dealing with the fallout and rectifying the error can take effort, resources and time that administrators could spend focusing on other things. Reviewing quality control processes and mechanisms regularly can reduce risk and help to minimise errors recurring in the future.
What is quality assurance?
QA is a systematic process of verifying and validating the accuracy and reliability of calculations, administrative processes and the member communications that go with them.

It acts as a safeguard, ensuring that calculations, communications and scheme processes are precise, compliant, and transparent, promoting trust amongst members, trustees and wider stakeholders alike.

QA encompasses a range of activities. This can range from reviewing individual calculations before issue (including the end-to-end calculation process from the receipt of data to the member communication) to auditing entire systems and processes on a regular basis.
The ultimate goal is to identify and rectify errors before they reach scheme members.

Conclusion

Quality assurance is not about ticking boxes; it is about safeguarding the future of scheme members and ensuring the integrity of the pension scheme. As we continue to navigate an ever-evolving regulatory landscape, the role of QA becomes more critical.

Pensions professionals are committed to ensuring that members receive the right benefits at the right time, first time, every time. By championing and prioritising QA within our individual schemes we can continue to build robust, trustworthy, and efficient pension systems that stand the test of time and foster a culture of excellence across our industry.
